value.name: SN 1998bw - Wikipedia
value.snippet: SN 1998bw was a rare broad-lined Type Ic gamma ray burst supernova detected on 26 April 1998 in the ESO 184-G82 spiral galaxy, which some astronomers believe may be an example of a collapsar . The supernova has been linked to GRB 980425 , which was detected on 25 April 1998, the first time a gamma-ray burst has been linked to a supernova. [3]

value.name: IAUC 6982: 1998di; CATACLYSMIC Var IN Peg; 1998an, 1998bn, 1998bp ...
value.snippet: SN 1998di is located at R.A. = 19h24m38s.19, Decl. = +59o41'46".7 (equinox 2000.0), which is about 0".6 east and 3".8 north of the nucleus of an anonymous galaxy. The new object was confirmed on a frame taken on Aug. 3.26. No star is present at this position on a frame taken on July 22.46 using the same equipment (limiting mag about 19).

value.name: SN 1998bp in NGC 6495
value.snippet: Compared with the reported magnitudes, it is not likely that SN 1998bp is especially sub-luminous as 1991bg, as Dr. Taichi Kato noted. Followup photometry and spectroscopy is strongly encouraged. Particularly, because the decline rate after the maximum is thought to be another indicator of the luminosities of SNeIa, it is very important to develop the light curve.

value.name: SN 1998bw and Other Hyperenergetic Type Ic Supernovae - Cambridge
value.snippet: The SN was immediately recognized as SN 1998bw-like from its broad spectral features [5, 7, 16, 29]. Luckily, the SN was discovered very soon after it exploded: the discovery date was Jan. 29, while the SN was not detected on Jan. 25 [32]. This is among the earliest any SN has been observed.
